sections.heading: The Golden Rule
sections.content:
The verb must be last. Everything else is surprisingly flexible.

私は昨日図書館で本を読んだ ✓ 昨日私は図書館で本を読んだ ✓ 図書館で私は昨日本を読んだ ✓

All three are grammatically correct. The verb 読んだ (read) stays at the end.

sections.heading: Standard Word Order
sections.content:
While flexible, Japanese has a default order that sounds most natural:

[Time] [Topic/Subject] [Indirect Object] [Location] [Direct Object] [Verb]

children.heading: Example Breakdown
children.content: 昨日 私は 友達に 図書館で 本を 貸した Time Topic Recipient Location Object Verb "Yesterday I lent a book to my friend at the library"

sections.heading: Time Expressions First
sections.content:
Time words typically come at the start:

✓ 今日私は学校に行く Today I go to school ✗ 私は今日学校に行く (less natural)

Common time words:

今日 (kyou) - today 昨日 (kinou) - yesterday 明日 (ashita) - tomorrow 今 (ima) - now さっき (sakki) - just now

sections.heading: Topic/Subject Early
sections.content:
The topic (は) or subject (が) comes early, usually right after time:

今日田中さんは来ません "Today, Tanaka won't come" 雨が降っている "Rain is falling"

sections.heading: Particles Define Roles, Not Position
sections.content:
This is why word order can be flexible:

私は彼に本をあげた 私は本を彼にあげた 本を私は彼にあげた

All mean "I gave him a book" because:

私は = topic marker (I) 彼に = indirect object (to him) 本を = direct object (book) Particles clarify roles regardless of position

sections.heading: Emphasis Through Position
sections.content: Put what you want to emphasize earlier in the sentence:

children.heading: Normal (neutral)
children.content: 私は昨日寿司を食べた "I ate sushi yesterday"

children.heading: Emphasize WHEN
children.content: 昨日、私は寿司を食べた "YESTERDAY, I ate sushi"

children.heading: Emphasize WHAT
children.content: 寿司を、昨日食べた "SUSHI is what I ate yesterday"

sections.heading: Modifiers Before Modified
sections.content: This rule is strict: Modifiers always come before what they modify

children.heading: Adjectives Before Nouns
children.content: ✓ 大きい犬 big dog ✗ 犬大きい

children.heading: Relative Clauses Before Nouns
children.content: ✓ 昨日買った本 the book (I) bought yesterday ✗ 本昨日買った

children.heading: の Phrases
children.content: ✓ 私の本 my book ✗ 本の私

sections.heading: Numbers and Counters
sections.content:
Numbers + counters come before the noun or after the object marker:

✓ 三冊の本を読んだ ✓ 本を三冊読んだ "I read three books" ✗ 読んだ三冊の本

sections.heading: Question Words
sections.content:
Question words typically go where the answer would be:

誰が来ますか？ "Who is coming?" (Someone is coming → Who is coming?) どこに行きますか？ "Where are you going?" (Going to somewhere → Going to where?) 何を食べますか？ "What will you eat?" (Eat something → Eat what?)

sections.heading: Adverbs Position
sections.content:
Adverbs are flexible but typically come before the verb:

✓ 私はよく寿司を食べる "I often eat sushi" ✓ よく私は寿司を食べる "Often, I eat sushi" (emphasis)

Common adverbs:

よく (yoku) - often ときどき (tokidoki) - sometimes 全然 (zenzen) - not at all (with negative) とても (totemo) - very

sections.heading: Multiple Clauses
sections.content:
In complex sentences, each clause maintains its own word order:

私は朝ごはんを食べて、学校に行った "I ate breakfast and went to school" Clause 1: 朝ごはんを食べて (ate breakfast) Clause 2: 学校に行った (went to school)

Conjunctions come between clauses, but verbs stay at the end of each.

children.heading: Pattern 1: Simple Statement
children.content: [Topic] は [Complement] です 私は学生です "I am a student"

children.heading: Pattern 2: Existence
children.content: [Location] に [Thing] が ある/いる 部屋に猫がいる "There's a cat in the room"

children.heading: Pattern 3: Action
children.content: [Topic] は [Object] を [Verb] 私は水を飲む "I drink water"

children.heading: Pattern 4: Movement
children.content: [Topic] は [Destination] に/へ [Verb] 東京に行く "Go to Tokyo"

children.heading: 1. Verb Must Be Last
children.content: ✓ 私は本を読む ✗ 私は読む本を ✗ 読む私は本を

children.heading: 2. Modifier Before Modified
children.content: ✓ 赤い車 ✗ 車赤い ✓ 私が買った本 ✗ 本私が買った

children.heading: 3. Particles Stay With Their Word
children.content: ✓ 私は本を読む ✗ 私本はを読む (particles misplaced)

sections.heading: Contractions and Casual Speech
sections.content:
In casual conversation, particles and words can be dropped, but the core order remains:

Formal: 私は今日学校に行きました Casual: 今日学校行った (私は and に dropped, but order same)

children.heading: Japanese (Flexible)
children.content: 私は 昨日 寿司を 食べた ✓ 昨日 私は 寿司を 食べた ✓ 寿司を 昨日 食べた ✓ (私は understood)

children.heading: English (Fixed)
children.content: I ate sushi yesterday ✓ Yesterday I ate sushi ✓ Sushi yesterday ate I ✗

sections.heading: Priority Order (Most Natural)
sections.content:
When in doubt, use this order:

Time - 今日、昨日 Topic - 私は、田中さんは Indirect Object - 友達に、先生に Location - 図書館で、家で Direct Object - 本を、寿司を Manner/Degree - ゆっくり、たくさん Verb - 食べる、行く

children.heading: Example Using All Elements
children.content: 昨日 私は 友達に 図書館で 本を ゆっくり 読んだ Time Topic Recipient Location Object Manner Verb "Yesterday I slowly read a book to my friend at the library"

children.heading: Mistake 1: Verb Not Last
children.content: Wrong: 私は食べる寿司を ❌ Right: 私は寿司を食べる ✓

children.heading: Mistake 2: Modifier After Noun
children.content: Wrong: 本新しい ❌ Right: 新しい本 ✓

children.heading: Mistake 3: Particle in Wrong Place
children.content: Wrong: を私本は読む ❌ Right: 私は本を読む ✓

children.heading: Mistake 4: Copying English Order Exactly
children.content: Wrong: 私は好き寿司を ❌ (Direct translation of "I like sushi") Right: 私は寿司が好き ✓

sections.heading: Tips for Natural Order
sections.content: Start with time if relevant Establish topic/subject early Build up details (location, manner) Object comes just before verb Verb always last

sections.heading: Practice Framework
sections.content:
Build sentences step by step:

Step 1: 読む (read) - choose verb Step 2: 本を読む (read a book) - add object Step 3: 図書館で本を読む (read at library) - add location Step 4: 私は図書館で本を読む (I read at library) - add topic Step 5: 昨日私は図書館で本を読んだ (Yesterday I read at library) - add time

sections.heading: Key Takeaways
sections.content:
✓ Verb must be last (only strict rule) ✓ Particles enable word order flexibility ✓ Modifiers before modified (strict) ✓ Time typically comes first ✓ Emphasis through position ✓ Standard order sounds most natural

Understanding these rules lets you construct clear sentences and recognize emphasis in native speech.

Next: Topic vs Subject

Related:

Sentence Structure (SOV) Particles Overview は (wa) vs が (ga)
